notes:
1. Concept

The Froude Number (Fr) is a dimensionless number defined as the ratio of the flow inertia to the external field (usually gravity). It is a critical parameter in open-channel flow (like rivers and canals) and wave mechanics.

2. Formula

For a rectangular channel, the Froude number is given by:

$$ Fr = \frac{v}{\sqrt{gy}} $$
  • $v$: Flow velocity.
  • $g$: Acceleration due to gravity.
  • $y$: Hydraulic depth (cross-sectional area / top width).

3. Flow Regimes

The Froude number determines the flow regime in open channels:

  • Subcritical Flow ($Fr < 1$): Also called 'tranquil' flow. The flow velocity is lower than the wave velocity ($v < \sqrt{gy}$). Disturbances can travel upstream.
  • Critical Flow ($Fr = 1$): The specific energy is at a minimum for a given discharge. $v = \sqrt{gy}$.
  • Supercritical Flow ($Fr > 1$): Also called 'rapid' or 'shooting' flow. The flow velocity is higher than the wave velocity. Disturbances cannot travel upstream.
